In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the function written in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump::Int=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date   # If dt is a Date type, throw an error
        throw(ArgumentError("Input must be of DateTime type.")) 
    else
        return dt + Hour(bump)  # Increase the time by bump hours
    end
end
```
In this function, `Dates` is a standard Julia module which provides functionality for dealing with dates and times. The `DateTime` type represents date-time values (i.e., date and time of day), and `Date` is the date part only.

The `typeof(dt)` function returns the data type of an object in Julia.

If `dt` is a `Date`, it throws an `ArgumentError`. If not, it adds `bump` hours to `dt` and return the new `DateTime`.
